article:
I used to watch her from my kitchen window and laugh. She seemed very small as she pushed her way through the crowd of 'boys on the playground. I remember the first day I saw her playing basketball. I   _  in wonder as she ran circles around the other   _    . She managed to jump just over their heads and   _   the basketball into the net. The boys always tried to   _     her but no one could.
     I   _   to notice her at other times, on that same playground, basketball in hand, playing    _   . She would practice moving  _  with the basketball and shooting  over and again  sometimes until dark.
     One day in her senior year, I saw her sitting in the grass, head  _  in her arms. I walked across the street and sat down in the cool   _  beside her. Quietly I asked what was  _      . "Oh, nothing", came a soft   _   . "I am just too short. "The coach told her that she would probably never be able to play for a top ranked team-much less   _   a  scholarship-so she had to stop    _   about college. She was heartbroken. I asked her if she had talked to her dad about it  _   .
She told me that her father said those coaches were wrong. They just did not   _   the power of a dream. He told her that if she really wanted to play for a good college, 57 _ could stop her except one thing-her own   _    . He told her again,  "If the dream is big enough, the facts don't   _    ."
     The next year she was seen by a recruiter ( ), and then she was offered a scholarship to NCAA women's basketball team. She finally got the chance for the college   _    that she had dreamed of and worked toward 'for all those years.
